4. Axis of the Conic Section

The axis of a conic section is the straight line passing through the focus and perpendicular to the directrix. This axis serves as a line of symmetry for the conic.

Types of Axes in Different Conic Sections
  • Parabola: The axis is called the axis of symmetry, passing through the focus and perpendicular to the directrix.
  • Ellipse and Hyperbola: These have two axes:
    • Major axis: The longer axis passes through both foci.
    • Minor axis: The shorter axis is perpendicular to the major axis.

5. Vertex of the Conic Section

The vertex of a conic section is the point of intersection between the conic and its axis. It represents the point where the curve bends.

How the Vertex Works in Different Conic Sections?
  • Parabola: The vertex is the midpoint between the focus and directrix.
  • Ellipse: The ellipse has two vertices, which are the endpoints of the major axis.
  • Hyperbola: The hyperbola has two vertices, marking the points where the branches of the curve are closest together.

Various Properties of a Parabola

In a standard parabola of the form y² = 4ax, several important properties define its geometric characteristics. The focus of the parabola is located at (a, 0), and the directrix is given by the vertical line x + a = 0. The axis of symmetry is the x-axis (y = 0) which passes through both the focus and the vertex at the origin ((0, 0)). Since the vertex is the midpoint between the focus and the directrix, every point on the parabola satisfies the fundamental property that its distance to the focus equals its perpendicular distance to the directrix.

In a standard parabola of the form y² = 4ax, the focus is (a, 0), the directrix is x + a = 0, the axis of symmetry is y = 0, and the vertex is (0, 0).
